description:
The Wiener Holocaust Library is one of the world’s leading and most extensive archives on the Holocaust. 

Visit to view our latest exhibition 'Looted: Two Families, Nazi Theft and the Search for Restitution' which unearths difficult questions about memory, responsibility and justice through the personal story of two families' project of restitution and restoration.

events.name: Drop in: Open Day
events.notes: Drop in to visit the Wiener Holocaust Library and our new exhibition "Looted: Two Families, Nazi Theft and the Search for Restitution".

events.name: Archive Tour
events.notes: Gain an in-depth view of our historic collections and see first-hand how we collect and preserve valuable material for future generations.

facilities: Handrails on one side of stairs

factsheet.heading: The Origins of the Library
paragraphs: Founded in 1933 by Dr. Alfred Wiener, the Wiener Holocaust Library is the world’s oldest Holocaust memorial institution. It was initially set up to collect and disseminate information about events happening in Nazi Germany.

Having moved to London in 1939, Dr Wiener’s collection proved invaluable, first to the British government and later, after the War, to the UN War crimes commission. Now a forum for research and scholarly debate, the Library is also known for gathering and compiling thousands of eyewitness accounts.

The Library’s current holdings number approximately 65,000 books and pamphlets, as well as periodicals, unpublished memoirs, photographs, press cuttings, and rare material obtained from all over the world.

factsheet.heading: The Present Building
paragraphs: In 2010 the Library acquired from Birkbeck, University of London, a 99-year lease on a substantial but dilapidated listed Georgian building, located at 29 Russell Square, in the heart of Bloomsbury. This was carefully refurbished and converted by Barbara Weiss Architects, to accommodate the collection in elegant, accessible, and climate controlled conditions – part of a £5m project intended to prepare the Library to play a more prominent role in British and international academic life.

The move was very much seen by the Library as the foundation for ensuring the appropriate conditions for its future work in scholarship, public policy and education relating to the study of the Holocaust, antisemitism and comparative genocide.

factsheet.heading: Current Exhibition: Looted
paragraphs: Our current exhibition 'Looted: Two Families, Nazi Theft and the Search for Restitution' concerns property valued at hundreds of billions of pounds which was looted from Jews in Europe under the Nazis. The exhibition explores an ordinary object with an extraordinary history. It unearths difficult questions about memory, responsibility and justice through the personal story of two families' project of restitution and restoration.

factsheet.heading: Architectural Team
paragraphs:
Architect: Barbara Weiss Architects Ltd 
Project manager and QS: Cluttons LLP 
Structural Engineer: Bartons Engineers Ltd 
Services Engineer: Peter Deer and Associates 
Main Contractor: BW Interiors Ltd
For more info on this building visit AJ Buildings Library http://www.ajbuildingslibrary.co.uk/projects/display/id/4945
